history.content:
Going into Mobile App Development is easy, if you know and understand what you were taught in 61AB and how to use this to your advantage. Javascript knowledge (jsNode is ok) will come in handy, as it will give you an understanding of what listeners are, something that happens to be very recurrent in mobile app dev and that is hard to grasp (initially) if you've never coded using listeners before. I cannot talk about Swift, but the transition from 61A into Android Mobile App Development was pretty reasonable for me.

I had never done real object oriented programming before. This was probably the main obstacle for me when I started to code on Java, but was something that I picked up in the way in a quick time due to what I had already learned about object oriented programming in 61A. With 61B under your wing, the change will be far less drastic (just syntax, listeners, and intents). The skills are easy to pick up and you will find yourself coding stuff in a small amount of time. My recommendation is bouncing into video tutorials, documentation, and Stack Overflow when in doubt. Except for a couple of things that are not carried on into Mobile Dev and activities and fragments, it will be very similar to Java (in the sense that most of what you will be coding will be object oriented). These "mobile app dev skills" can be easily picked up following a series of video tutorials on Coursera, Udacity, or with Google (they have many video tutorials explaining the fundamentals of Mobile App Dev for Android). 

If I were you, I'd go with Android Dev rather than with iOS dev. Android Dev will happen more naturally, because you already know Java. Android also has by far many more users. This might not seem obvious to you if you are from California, but in most countries around the world, Android is by far more common than iOS. Also, learning to do app dev in Android will be a skill that will be more useful to you in Software Engineering or Mobile App Dev in general than Swift, and will make you employable in more places. This if you are looking at this long term. If you are looking at this short term, you should focus on improving your current skills rather than trying to do everything, which is why I would still recommend you to do Android Dev over iOS dev, at least for now

children.subject:
This is straight up obvious. Java is a language that is by far more popular than Swift, as well as useful for other purposes other than Mobile App Dev. Honestly, as far as languages go, this is not a very important matter. A good programmer will not care about the language he has to use. But there is honestly no point on wasting time on learning Swift, when Java will suit more devices and is something that you already know and can use somewhere else (Swift is limiting in this aspect, it sees no use outside of iOS dev and this is a fact).

About the employment thing, it is widely known. Coming from Latam, and having traveled to other places that are not the US, you will almost instantly realize that most smartphone users abroad are Android and not iOS. This is a reality that does not only apply to Latam, but that you can also extrapolate to Asia, Europe, and Africa. The numbers vary, but are largely leaning towards Android's side of the court and are available here: 

https://9to5mac.com/2016/08/18/android-ios-smartphone-market-share/ 

https://android.jlelse.eu/apple-vs-android-a-comparative-study-2017-c5799a0a1683

https://www.forbes.com/sites/johnkoetsier/2017/05/18/surprise-google-reveals-apples-ios-market-share-is-65-to-230-bigger-than-we-thought/#6be3b24e5890

https://www.theverge.com/2017/2/16/14634656/android-ios-market-share-blackberry-2016

Hope this was helpful

"learning to do app dev in Android will be a skill that will be more useful to you in Software Engineering or Mobile App Dev in general than Swift, and will make you employable in more places" Any sources, articles, etc. to support this?
If you're interested in iOS Development, I highly recommend the materials here: http://iosdecal.com/.

This is not exactly true. Yes, there are developers that are moving towards react native development, but that is definitely not all. React Native is from Facebook. There is uncertainty whether react native will exist in a future from now. A year ago Facebook shut down Parse, a developer platform. Hopefully that will not happen with React Native, but you can't take that for granted. Additionally, Apple and Google do not directly endorse React Native. There are pros and cons about the whole thing here: https://www.varvet.com/blog/react-native-vs-native-in-mobile-app-development/. Also, check here: https://www.coursereport.com/blog/so-you-want-to-build-a-mobile-app-react-native-vs-native-mobile. It really boils down to what you want to do and if you are interested in the matter short or long term

i was under the impression react native is open-source, so why wouldn't it exist in the future even if facebook doesn't continue developing it?

I was just basing my answers off of stackoverflow's survey https://insights.stackoverflow.com/survey/2018/#technology where javascript leads language use, and the frameworks I mentioned are all popular. I have no idea which is better long-term.
i haven't actually followed through with any, but from my understanding, much modern mobile development is done using cross-platform javascript frameworks like react native, xamarin, cordova, etc.

history.content: I'd like to get started on developing an app as one of my main projects for the end of the semester/summer. It wouldn't be anything fancy/advanced, but just something simple to put everything I've learned to use. Thing is, the only programming knowledge/experience I have is 61A/B, some R knowledge, and DS 100. I'm willing to self-teach/learn whatever I need to. Am I "experienced" enough (in terms of foundational knowledge) to get started on this, or are there specific classes that would be invaluable for app development? Also, from what I understand, Android apps are mainly coded in Java while iOS uses their own language Swift. Are there no significant differences between the 2 platforms for first-time developers, or is there a platform I should focus on for learning/ease-of-adoption? Thanks.
history.subject: Questions about App Development
